properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Easterly winds gusting up to 90 km/h are expected this afternoon and evening. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-05T08:29:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-04T16:30:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0376632865.2020
Area: Blanc-Sablon
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected Thursday afternoon and evening. A low pressure system will track south of the area on Thursday. Snow is expected to begin late Thursday morning and continue through Thursday night before coming to an end Friday morning. Total snowfall amounts near 15 cm are possible with the highest amounts falling Thursday afternoon and evening. At this time, there is some uncertainty in the exact track of this low pressure system and associated snowfall amounts. Snowfall warnings may be required. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-05T08:39:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-04T16:40:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2328244783.2020
Area: Searchmont - Montreal River Harbour - Batchawana Bay, Sault Ste. Marie - St. Joseph Island, Elliot Lake - Ranger Lake, Blind River - Thessalon, Manitoulin Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow expected Thursday. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly near 60 km/h. Locations: Parson's Pond to Hawke's Bay. Time span: near noon Thursday to Thursday evening. Remarks: Rain and strong southeasterly winds are expected today. Please see the existing wind warning for further details. Overnight tonight, rain is expected to change to snow. By noon on Thursday, winds will strengthen and shift to the northwest. Snow and blowing snow will combine to cause poor visibility Thursday afternoon into the evening. Conditions will likely improve Thursday evening as the snow begins to taper off. There is some uncertainty with the total snowfall on Thursday. Please continue to monitor future alerts, as higher snowfall totals are possible. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-05T06:12:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-04T14:13:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0866565358.2020
Area: Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds expected today, tonight and Thursday. Maximum gusts: southwesterly 80 to 100 km/h. Locations: eastern Newfoundland including the northern Avalon Peninsula. Time span: overnight tonight until near noon Thursday. Remarks: Strongest wind gusts are expected along exposed areas of the coast. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 2 to 4 millimetres of freezing precipitation is expected this morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total freezing rain: 3 to 6 hours (5 to 10 mm). Locations: Humber Valley, Buchans, Green Bay - White Bay. Time span: ending this evening. Remarks: Precipitation will change to snow overnight tonight which will continue through Thursday. At this time, generally 5 to 10 cm is expected by the end of Thursday, with greater amounts over higher terrain between Deer Lake and Bonne Bay. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall with blowing snow is expected. Significant snowfall, ice pellets, strong winds, and blowing snow are expected. Total snow and ice pellet amounts: 15 to 25 cm. Maximum wind gusts: easterly 80 km/h. Locations: southeastern Labrador. Time span: early this evening until near midnight tonight. Remarks: Snow mixed at times with ice pellets will develop this evening, with a risk of freezing rain over some areas. The snow is expected to be heavy at times, and will be accompanied by strong winds resulting in poor visibility in blowing snow. The snow is forecast to change to a mixture of rain and snow near midnight, and to taper to flurries before morning on Thursday. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-05T05:59:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-04T14:31:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2831330632.2020

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall mixed with freezing precipitation is expected. Total Snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Freezing Rain: 4 to 6 hours of freezing rain (near 10 mm). Maximum Wind gusts: east to northeasterly 80 km/h. Locations: the Great Northern Peninsula. Time span: continuing until midnight tonight. Remarks: Areas that do not see any significant freezing rain will likely see significantly reduced visibility in snow and blowing snow as strong easterly winds develop early this evening. Conditions will improve near midnight as precipitation changes to drizzle with temperatures rising above zero briefly. Periods of snow will begin again in the overnight hours and persist into Thursday morning giving an additional 2 to 4 cm. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northerly 70 km/h. Locations: Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River, Cartwright to Black Tickle, and Postville - Makkovik. Time span: tonight to Friday morning. Remarks: Snow at times heavy will begin tonight and combine with strong northerly winds to create reduced visibility at times in blowing snow. While the snow and wind will persist through much of the day on Thursday in the north and the interior, the southeast can expect a brief reprieve as temperatures rise to zero and winds diminish. The wind and blowing snow is forecast to resume in the southeast late in the day on Thursday. Conditions are expected to improve for all locations by Friday morning. ### Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northerly 70 km/h. Locations: Rigolet and vicinity, as well as Hopedale and vicinity. Time span: tonight to Friday morning. Remarks: Snow will begin tonight and persist through Thursday before tapering to flurries Thursday night. Strong northerly winds will accompany the snow, reducing visibility in blowing snow. In Rigolet, the worst conditions are expected during the overnight hours tonight before temperatures warm to near zero, which will hamper the ability for the snow to blow around and reduce visibility. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall, strong winds, and localized blowing snow are expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 30 cm, with higher amounts possible over elevated terrain. Maximum wind gusts: southwesterly 100 km/h. Locations: Burgeo and the west coast from Channel-Port aux Basques to Gros Morne. Time span: this evening until Thursday evening. Remarks: Rain is expected to change over to snow at times heavy this evening. The snow will be accompanied by strong southwesterly winds causing blowing snow over exposed areas overnight. Blowing snow will become more widespread on Thursday along the west coast as temperatures dip below zero. ### Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills continues. The coldest wind chill values will be between minus 50 and minus 55. These very cold wind chills will moderate by this afternoon. However Wind chills may dip below minus 50 again by Thursday morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A low pressure system off southeast Alaska will send Pacific moisture onto the Alaskan Panhandle today and especially tonight. At the same time cold arctic air will begin to rush out to the coast later tonight. Consequently, periods of snow today will become heavy at times this evening. Strong north winds gusting to 70 km/h will then develop by midnight giving widespread blowing snow. Total snowfall accumulations of 15 to 25 cm are forecast by Thursday morning with wind chill values lowering to minus 30 overnight. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-05T06:15:50-00:00

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall, combined with melting snow, is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Total rainfall: 15 to 25 mm. Locations: Burin and Avalon peninsulas. Time span: ending this evening. Remarks: Rain, at times heavy, and strong southerly winds will cause significant snow melt and runoff this evening. Minor localized flooding is likely in areas prone to winter drainage problems. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. An approaching frontal system will move onto the BC coast tonight. Ahead of the front, southeast winds of 80 to 100 km/h will develop this evening then ease overnight. For Haida Gwaii, strong winds will veer to the southwest overnight before diminishing on Thursday. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
